| Section3 = {{Chembox Hazards Solubility = MainHazards = FlashPt =
| Autoignition =
  }} }} 'Thiamine pyrophosphate' (TPP or ThPP), or 'thiamine diphosphate'
  (ThDP), is a thiamine (vitamin B 1) derivative which is produced by
  the enzyme thiamine pyrophosphatase. Thiamine pyrophosphate is a cofactor
  that is present in all living systems, in which it catalyzes several
  biochemical reactions. It was first discovered as an essential nutrient
  (vitamin) in humans through its link with the peripheral nervous system
  disease Beriberi, which results from a deficiency of thiamine in the
  diet.

TPP works as a coenzyme in many enzymatic reactions, such as:

* Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex
* Pyruvate decarboxylase in ethanol fermentation
* Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex
* Branched-chain amino acid dehydrogenase complex
* 2-hydroxyphytanoyl-CoA lyase
* Transketolase
